args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the looked up blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the blob.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

git_blob_lookup.description: Lookup a blob object from a repository. The generated blob object is owned by the revision repo and shall not be freed by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: The repository where the object will reside

git_blob_new.comments: The blob object must be manually filled using the 'set_rawcontent' methods before it can be written back to disk.

args.name: filename
args.comment: name of the file to read

git_blob_set_rawcontent_fromfile.description: Fill a blob with the contents inside the pointed file.

args.name: buffer
args.comment: buffer with the contents for the blob

git_blob_set_rawcontent.description: Fill a blob with the contents inside the pointed buffer

return.comment: the pointer; NULL if the blob has no contents

git_blob_rawcontent.description: Get a read-only buffer with the raw content of a blob.
git_blob_rawcontent.comments: A pointer to the raw content of a blob is returned; this pointer is owned internally by the object and shall not be free'd. The pointer may be invalidated at a later time (e.g. when changing the contents of the blob).

git_blob_rawsize.description: Get the size in bytes of the contents of a blob

args.name: written_id
args.comment: return the id of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where the blob will be written

args.name: path
args.comment: file from which the blob will be created

git_blob_writefile.description: Read a file from the working folder of a repository and write it to the Object Database as a loose blob, if such doesn't exist yet.

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment:
identity of the commit to locate.  If the object is
        an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

git_commit_lookup.description: Lookup a commit object from a repository. The generated commit object is owned by the revision repo and shall not be freed by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: The repository where the object will reside

git_commit_new.comments: The commit object must be manually filled using setter methods before it can be written to its repository.

return.comment: the short message of a commit

git_commit_message_short.description: Get the short (one line) message of a commit.

git_commit_message.description: Get the full message of a commit.

git_commit_time.description: Get the commit time (i.e. committer time) of a commit.

return.comment: positive or negative timezone offset, in minutes from UTC

git_commit_time_offset.description: Get the commit timezone offset (i.e. committer's preferred timezone) of a commit.

git_commit_tree.description: Get the tree pointed to by a commit.

git_commit_parentcount.description: Get the number of parents of this commit

return.comment: a pointer to the commit; NULL if out of bounds

git_commit_parent.description: Get the specified parent of the commit.

args.name: new_parent
args.comment: the new commit which will be a parent

git_commit_add_parent.description: Add a new parent commit to an existing commit

git_commit_set_tree.description: Set the tree which is pointed to by a commit

args.name: index
args.comment: the pointer for the new index

args.name: index_path
args.comment: the path to the index file in disk

git_index_open_bare.description: Create a new Git index object as a memory representation of the Git index file in 'index_path', without a repository to back it.
git_index_open_bare.comments: Since there is no ODB behind this index, any Index methods which rely on the ODB (e.g. index_add) will fail with the GIT_EBAREINDEX error code.

args.name: repo
args.comment: the git repo which owns the index

git_index_open_inrepo.description: Open the Index inside the git repository pointed by 'repo'.

git_index_clear.description: Clear the contents (all the entries) of an index object. This clears the index object in memory; changes must be manually written to disk for them to take effect.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_read.description: Update the contents of an existing index object in memory by reading from the hard disk.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_write.description: Write an existing index object from memory back to disk using an atomic file lock.

git_index_find.description: Find the first index of any entires which point to given path in the Git index.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_add.description: Add or update an index entry from a file in disk.

args.name: position
args.comment: position of the entry to remove

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code
0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_insert.description: Insert an entry into the index. A full copy (including the 'path' string) of the given 'source_entry' will be inserted on the index; if the index already contains an entry for the same path, the entry will be updated.

return.comment: a pointer to the entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get.description: Get a pointer to one of the entries in the index
git_index_get.comments: This entry can be modified, and the changes will be written back to disk on the next write() call.

return.comment: integer of count of current entries

git_index_entrycount.description: Get the count of entries currently in the index

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: the unique identifier for the object

git_object_lookup.argline: git_object **object, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, git_otype type
git_object_lookup.description: Lookup a reference to one of the objects in a repostory.
git_object_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and should not be freed by the user.

The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object in the odb; the method will fail otherwise. The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let the method guess the object's type.

args.name: type
args.comment: Type of the object to be created

git_object_new.description: Create a new in-memory repository object with the given type.
git_object_new.comments:
The object's attributes can be filled in using the corresponding setter methods.

The object will be written back to given git_repository when the git_object_write() function is called; objects cannot be written to disk until all their main attributes have been properly filled.

Objects are instantiated with no SHA1 id; their id will be automatically generated when writing to the repository.

return.comment: 0 on success; otherwise an error code

git_object_write.comments:
The object will be written to its corresponding repository.

If the object has no changes since it was first read from the repository, no actions will take place.

If the object has been modified since it was read from the repository, or it has been created from scratch in memory, it will be written to the repository and its SHA1 ID will be updated accordingly.

git_object_id.description: Get the id (SHA1) of a repository object
git_object_id.comments: In-memory objects created by git_object_new() do not have a SHA1 ID until they are written on a repository.

git_object_type.description: Get the object type of an object

return.comment: the repository who owns this object

git_object_owner.description: Get the repository that owns this object

git_object_close.comments:
This method instructs the library to close an existing object; note that git_objects are owned by the repository and are reference counted, so the object may or may not be freed after this library call, depending on whether any other objects still depend on it.

IMPORTANT: It is not necessary to call this method when you stop using an object, since all object memory is automatically reclaimed by the repository when it is freed.

Forgetting to call git_object_close does not cause memory leaks, but it's is recommended to close as soon as possible the biggest objects (e.g. blobs) to prevent wasting memory space.

git_object_type2string.description: Convert an object type to it's string representation.
git_object_type2string.comments: The result is a pointer to a string in static memory and should not be free()'ed.

git_object_string2type.description: Convert a string object type representation to it's git_otype.

return.comment:
true if the type represents a valid loose object type,
 false otherwise.

git_object_typeisloose.description: Determine if the given git_otype is a valid loose object type.

args.name: type
args.comment: object type to get its size

return.comment: size in bytes of the object

git_object__size.description: Get the size in bytes for the structure which acts as an in-memory representation of any given object type.
git_object__size.comments: For all the core types, this would the equivalent of calling sizeof(git_commit) if the core types were not opaque on the external API.

args.name: out
args.comment:
location to store the database pointer, if opened.
            Set to NULL if the open failed.

return.comment:
GIT_SUCCESS if the database was created; otherwise an error
         code describing why the open was not possible.

git_odb_new.description: Create a new object database with no backends.
git_odb_new.comments: Before the ODB can be used for read/writing, a custom database backend must be manually added using git_odb_add_backend()

args.name: out
args.comment:
location to store the database pointer, if opened.
            Set to NULL if the open failed.

return.comment:
GIT_SUCCESS if the database opened; otherwise an error
         code describing why the open was not possible.

git_odb_open.description: Create a new object database and automatically add the two default backends:
git_odb_open.comments:
- git_odb_backend_loose: read and write loose object files
    from disk, assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder

- git_odb_backend_pack: read objects from packfiles,
    assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder which
    contains a 'pack/' folder with the corresponding data

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

git_odb_add_backend.description: Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

git_odb_add_alternate.description: Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB; this backend will work as an alternate.
git_odb_add_alternate.comments:
Alternate backends are always checked for objects after all the main backends have been exhausted.

Writing is disabled on alternate backends.

Read for more information.

args.name: db
args.comment: database pointer to close.  If NULL no action is taken.

args.name: out
args.comment: object descriptor to populate upon reading.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment:
- GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read;
 - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read.comments: If GIT_ENOTFOUND then out->data is set to NULL.

args.name: out
args.comment: object descriptor to populate upon reading.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment:
- GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read;
 - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read_header.description: Read the header of an object from the database, without reading its full contents.
git_odb_read_header.comments:
Only the 'type' and 'len' fields of the git_rawobj structure are filled. The 'data' pointer will always be NULL.

The raw object pointed by 'out' doesn't need to be manually closed with git_rawobj_close().

args.name: db
args.comment: database to which the object should be written.

args.name: obj
args.comment: object descriptor for the object to write.

return.comment:
- GIT_SUCCESS if the object was written;
 - GIT_ERROR otherwise.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to be searched for the given object.

return.comment:
- true, if the object was found
 - false, otherwise

git_odb_exists.description: Determine if the given object can be found in the object database.

args.name: obj
args.comment: the object whose hash is to be determined.

return.comment:
- GIT_SUCCESS if the object-ID was correctly determined.
 - GIT_ERROR if the given object is malformed.

git_rawobj_hash.description: Determine the object-ID (sha1 hash) of the given git_rawobj.
git_rawobj_hash.comments: The input obj must be a valid loose object type and the data pointer must not be NULL, unless the len field is also zero.

git_rawobj_close.description: Release all memory used by the obj structure.
git_rawobj_close.comments:
As a result of this call, obj->data will be set to NULL.

If obj->data is already NULL, nothing happens.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment:
input hex string; must be pointing at the start of
        the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes
        needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if valid; GIT_ENOTOID on failure.

git_oid_mkstr.description: Parse a hex formatted object id into a git_oid.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: raw
args.comment: the raw input bytes to be copied.

git_oid_mkraw.description: Copy an already raw oid into a git_oid structure.

args.name: str
args.comment:
output hex string; must be pointing at the start of
        the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes
        needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).  Only the
        oid digits are written; a '
\
0' terminator must be added
        by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_fmt.description: Format a git_oid into a hex string.

args.name: str
args.comment:
output hex string; must be pointing at the start of
        the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes
        needed for an oid encoded in hex (41 bytes).  Only the
        oid digits are written; a '
\
0' terminator must be added
        by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_pathfmt.description:
Format a git_oid into a loose-object path string.

The resulting string is "aa/...", where "aa" is the first two hex digitis of the oid and "..." is the remaining 38 digits.

return.comment:
the c-string; NULL if memory is exhausted.  Caller must
         deallocate the string with free().

git_oid_allocfmt.description: Format a gid_oid into a newly allocated c-string.

args.name: out
args.comment: the buffer into which the oid string is output.

args.name: n
args.comment: the size of the out buffer.

return.comment:
the out buffer pointer, assuming no input parameter
         errors, otherwise a pointer to an empty string.

git_oid_to_string.description:
Format a git_oid into a buffer as a hex format c-string.

If the buffer is smaller than GIT_OID_HEXSZ+1, then the resulting oid c-string will be truncated to n-1 characters. If there are any input parameter errors (out == NULL, n == 0, oid == NULL), then a pointer to an empty string is returned, so that the return value can always be printed.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

git_oid_cpy.description: Copy an oid from one structure to another.

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the reference

args.name: name
args.comment: the long name for the reference (e.g. HEAD, ref/heads/master, refs/tags/v0.1.0, ...)

git_reference_lookup.description: Lookup a reference by its name in a repository.
git_reference_lookup.comments: The generated reference is owned by the repository and should not be freed by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

git_reference_create_symbolic.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const char *target
git_reference_create_symbolic.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written to the disk.

This reference is owned by the repository and shall not be free'd by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: id
args.comment: The object id pointed to by the reference.

git_reference_create_oid.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const git_oid *id
git_reference_create_oid.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written to the disk.

This reference is owned by the repository and shall not be free'd by the user.

return.comment: a pointer to the oid if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_oid.description: Get the OID pointed to by a reference.
git_reference_oid.comments: Only available if the reference is direct (i.e. not symbolic)

return.comment: a pointer to the name if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_target.description: Get full name to the reference pointed by this reference
git_reference_target.comments: Only available if the reference is symbolic

return.comment: the full name for the ref

git_reference_name.description: Get the full name of a reference

git_reference_resolve.comments:
Thie method iteratively peels a symbolic reference until it resolves to a direct reference to an OID.

If a direct reference is passed as an argument, that reference is returned immediately

git_reference_owner.description: Get the repository where a reference resides

args.name: target
args.comment: The new target for the reference

git_reference_set_target.description: Set the symbolic target of a reference.
git_reference_set_target.comments:
The reference must be a symbolic reference, otherwise this method will fail.

The reference will be automatically updated in memory and on disk.

git_reference_set_oid.description: Set the OID target of a reference.
git_reference_set_oid.comments:
The reference must be a direct reference, otherwise this method will fail.

The reference will be automatically updated in memory and on disk.

git_reference_rename.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references. The new name will be checked for validity and may be modified into a normalized form.

The refernece will be immediately renamed in-memory and on disk.

git_reference_delete.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.

The reference will be immediately removed on disk and from memory. The given reference pointer will no longer be valid.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where the loose refs will be packed

git_reference_packall.description: Pack all the loose references in the repository
git_reference_packall.comments:
This method will load into the cache all the loose references on the repository and update the packed-refs file with them.

Once the packed-refs file has been written properly, the loose references will be removed from disk.

WARNING: calling this method may invalidate any existing references previously loaded on the cache.

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

git_repository_open.comments:
The 'path' argument must point to an existing git repository folder, e.g.

    /path/to/my_repo/.git/  (normal repository)
                        objects/
                        index
                        HEAD

    /path/to/bare_repo/     (bare repository)
                    objects/
                    index
                    HEAD

The method will automatically detect if 'path' is a normal
or bare repository or fail is 'path' is neither.

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

args.name: git_dir
args.comment:
The full path to the repository folder
		e.g. a '.git' folder for live repos, any folder for bare
		Equivalent to $GIT_DIR. 
		Cannot be NULL.

args.name: git_object_directory
args.comment:
The full path to the ODB folder.
		the folder where all the loose and packed objects are stored
		Equivalent to $GIT_OBJECT_DIRECTORY.
		If NULL, "$GIT_DIR/objects/" is assumed.

args.name: git_index_file
args.comment:
The full path to the index (dircache) file
		Equivalent to $GIT_INDEX_FILE.
		If NULL, "$GIT_DIR/index" is assumed.

args.name: git_work_tree
args.comment:
The full path to the working tree of the repository,
		if the repository is not bare.
		Equivalent to $GIT_WORK_TREE.
		If NULL, the repository is assumed to be bare.

git_repository_open2.argline: git_repository **repository, const char *git_dir, const char *git_object_directory, const char *git_index_file, const char *git_work_tree
git_repository_open2.description: Open a git repository by manually specifying all its paths

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

args.name: git_dir
args.comment:
The full path to the repository folder
		e.g. a '.git' folder for live repos, any folder for bare
		Equivalent to $GIT_DIR. 
		Cannot be NULL.

args.name: object_database
args.comment:
A pointer to a git_odb created 
&
 initialized
		by the user (e.g. with custom backends). This object database
		will be owned by the repository and will be automatically free'd.
		It should not be manually free'd by the user, or this
		git_repository object will become invalid.

args.name: git_index_file
args.comment:
The full path to the index (dircache) file
		Equivalent to $GIT_INDEX_FILE.
		If NULL, "$GIT_DIR/index" is assumed.

args.name: git_work_tree
args.comment:
The full path to the working tree of the repository,
		if the repository is not bare.
		Equivalent to $GIT_WORK_TREE.
		If NULL, the repository is assumed to be bare.

git_repository_open3.argline: git_repository **repository, const char *git_dir, git_odb *object_database, const char *git_index_file, const char *git_work_tree
git_repository_open3.description: Open a git repository by manually specifying its paths and the object database it will use.

return.comment: a pointer to the object db

git_repository_database.description: Get the object database behind a Git repository

args.name: index
args.comment: Pointer where to store the index

return.comment: 0 on success; error code if the index could not be opened

git_repository_index.description: Get the Index file of a Git repository
git_repository_index.comments: This is a cheap operation; the index is only opened on the first call, and subsequent calls only retrieve the previous pointer.

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

args.name: repo_out
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be created or reinitialized

args.name: is_bare
args.comment:
if true, a Git repository without a working directory is created 
		at the pointed path. If false, provided path will be considered as the working 
		directory into which the .git directory will be created.

git_repository_init.argline: git_repository **repo_out, const char *path, unsigned int is_bare
git_repository_init.description: Creates a new Git repository in the given folder.
git_repository_init.comments: TODO: - Reinit the repository - Create config files

args.name: walker
args.comment: pointer to the new revision walker

git_revwalk_new.description: Allocate a new revision walker to iterate through a repo.

git_revwalk_push.description: Mark a commit to start traversal from. The commit object must belong to the repo which is being walked through.

args.name: commit
args.comment: the commit that will be ignored during the traversal

git_revwalk_hide.description: Mark a commit (and its ancestors) uninteresting for the output.

args.name: commit
args.comment: Pointer where to store the next commit

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker to pop the commit from.

return.comment:
GIT_SUCCESS if the next commit was found;
	GIT_EREVWALKOVER if there are no commits left to iterate

git_revwalk_next.description: Get the next commit from the revision traversal.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

git_revwalk_sorting.description: Change the sorting mode when iterating through the repository's contents. Changing the sorting mode resets the walker.

args.name: walk
args.comment: traversal handle to close.  If NULL nothing occurs.

git_revwalk_repository.description: Return the repository on which this walker is operating.

return.comment: the new sig, NULl on out of memory

git_signature_new.description: Create a new action signature. The signature must be freed manually or using git_signature_free

email of the person

time when the action happened

timezone offset in minutes for the time

return.comment: a copy of sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_dup.description: Create a copy of an existing signature.
git_signature_dup.comments:
All internal strings are also duplicated.

signature to duplicated

 id OID for the tree entry

git_tree_add_entry.description: Add a new entry to a tree and return the new entry.

return.comment: 0 on successful removal; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the entry wasn't found

git_tree_remove_entry_byindex.comments:
Index must be >= 0 and < than git_tree_entrycount().

This will mark the tree as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: tree

return.comment: 0 on successful removal; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the entry wasn't found

args.name: tree

git_tree_clear_entries.comments: This will mark the tree as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write().

args.name: oid
args.comment: new SHA1 oid for the entry

git_tree_entry_set_id.description: Change the SHA1 id of a tree entry.
git_tree_entry_set_id.comments: This will mark the tree that contains the entry as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: entry
args.comment: Entry object which will be modified

git_tree_entry_set_name.description: Change the filename of a tree entry.
git_tree_entry_set_name.comments: This will mark the tree that contains the entry as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: entry
args.comment: Entry object which will be modified

git_tree_entry_set_attributes.description: Change the attributes of a tree entry.
git_tree_entry_set_attributes.comments: This will mark the tree that contains the entry as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

fields.name: GIT_OBJ_ANY
fields.comments: Object can be any of the following

fields.name: GIT_OBJ_OFS_DELTA
fields.comments: A delta, base is given by an offset.

fields.name: GIT_OBJ_REF_DELTA
fields.comments: A delta, base is given by object id.

types.block:
void * data
size_t len
git_otype type
types.description: An object read from the database.

fields.name: len
fields.comments: Total number of bytes in data.

types.description: In-memory representation of a reference.

Representation of an existing git repository,
 including all its object contents
Representation of an in-progress walk through the commits in a repo
Basic type of any Git reference.

fields.name: GIT_REF_SYMBOLIC
fields.comments: A reference which points at an object id

fields.name: GIT_REF_PACKED
fields.comments: A reference which points at another reference

fields.name: GIT_REF_HAS_PEEL
fields.comments: A reference which points at another reference
